  Sowerby }} {{mycomorphbox | name = Humaria hemisphaerica | whichGills =no | capShape = infundibuliform | hymeniumType=smooth | stipeCharacter=NA | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor= | howEdible=inedible }} '''''Humaria hemisphaerica''''', commonly known as the '''hairy fairy cup'''{{cite book |author=Arora D. |title=Mushrooms Demystified: A Comprehensive Guide to the Fleshy Fungi |publisher=Ten Speed Press |location=Berkeley, Calif |year=1986 |pages=839–840 |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate= |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} or the '''brown-haired fairy cup''',{{cite book |author=Roody WC. |title=Mushrooms of West Virginia and the Central Appalachians |publisher=University Press of Kentucky |location=Lexington, Ky |year=2003 |page=465|isbn=0-8131-9039-8}} is a [[species]] of fungi in the family [[Pyronemataceae]]. This [[mycorrhizal]] fungus is recognized by its white inner surface and hairy brown outer surface. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] is derived from the [[Latin language|Latin]] word ''hemisphaericum'', meaning half a sphere. ==Taxonomy== This species was originally described by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in 1823 as ''Peziza hemisphaerica''.Fries EM. (1823). ''Systema mycologicum''. Vol 2. Ex Officina Berlingiana, Lundae, Sweden. 620 pp. He considered it to be one of the ''Lachnia'', a name he applied to cup fungi with hairy [[apothecia]]. In 1870 [[Karl Wilhelm Gottlieb Leopold Fuckel|Leopold Fuckel]] transferred ''P. hemisphaerica'' to the genus ''[[Humaria]]''.Fuckel L. (1870). Symbolae mycologicae. Beiträge zur Kenntnis der rheinischen Pilze. ''Jahrbuch des Nassauischen Vereins für Naturkunde'' '''23–24''':1–459. ==Description== ''Humaria hemisphaerica'' has fruiting bodies ([[apothecia]]) that typically measure {{convert|2|to|3|cm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter by {{convert|1|to|1.5|cm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} deep.{{cite book|author1=Rosanne A. Healy |author2=Huffman, Donald R. |author3=Lois H. Tiffany |author4=George Knaphaus |title=Mushrooms and Other Fungi of the Midcontinental United States (Bur Oak Guide) |publisher=University of Iowa Press|location=Iowa City |year=2008 |page=279 |isbn=1-58729-627-6 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} The fruiting bodies are initially spherical and expand to become cuplike at the fungus matures. This species typically does not have a [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]]―when it does, it is present as a small abrupt base. The inner surface of the fruiting body (the [[hymenium]]) is white, while the outer hairy surface is brown and covered with brown hairs that taper to a sharp point. These hairs are 400–500 x 15–20 [[micrometre|μm]]. The [[ascospores]] are elliptical, [[hyaline]], 20–22 x 10–11 μm, and have 2–3 oil droplets.{{cite book |author=Tylutki, Edmund E. |title=Mushrooms of Idaho and the Pacific Northwest |publisher=University Press of Idaho|location=Moscow |year=1979 |page=90 |isbn=0-89301-062-6 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} The hairy fairy cup is inedible. ==Habitat== ''Humaria hemisphaerica'' grows solitary, scattered, or in groups on the ground or sometimes on rotten wood in wooded areas. ==Similar species== There are several other cup fungi with hairy exteriors that may be confused with ''H. hemisphaerica''. ''[[Jafnea semitotsa]]'' is larger (2–5 cm diameter) with a brown interior and a short stipe. ''[[Trichophaea boudieri]]'' and ''[[Trichophaea bullata]]'' are smaller (1–6 mm diameter).''[[Trichophaea abundans]]'' is another small species that prefers to grow in burned areas. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071015190218/http://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/SynSpecies.asp?RecordID=120602 Index Fungorum] {{Taxonbar|from=Q1570399}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Humaria Hemisphaerica}} [[Category:Pyronemataceae]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1870]]
